title: Lifestyle Expectations
description: Discover what kind of life you each envision and how money fits into that picture.

questions.text: When I think about the lifestyle I want, I prioritize...
choices: Flexibility to adapt as life changes

therapeutic.rationale: Lifestyle priorities reveal core values about what makes life good. Security-seekers need stability; comfort-seekers balance; experience-seekers prioritize memories; flexibility-seekers stay open. These values drive major financial decisions.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different lifestyle priorities can create tension about how to spend resources. The security-seeker may feel the experience-seeker is reckless; the experience-seeker may feel the security-seeker is missing out. Both are valid ways to live.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared lifestyle priorities make planning easier. You're naturally aiming for the same kind of life.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What does your ideal life look like day-to-day? What would you need financially to have that?

questions.text: My approach to lifestyle spending is...
choices: Live below our means and build wealth
Enjoy what we earn—life is short
Invest in things that improve quality of life
Keep it simple; less is more

therapeutic.rationale: Spending philosophy shapes daily life. Below-means builds wealth but may sacrifice joy; enjoy-now prioritizes experience but may sacrifice security; quality-investors balance; minimalists need less. Partners often have different philosophies.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different spending philosophies clash over everyday decisions. The saver may feel the enjoyer doesn't care about the future; the enjoyer may feel the saver is joyless. Find the philosophy that works for both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared spending philosophy makes daily financial life harmonious. You naturally agree on how to allocate resources.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel when you spend money on yourself? Guilty? Satisfied? Where does that feeling come from?

questions.text: When it comes to where we live, I value...
choices: Flexibility to move when life calls

therapeutic.rationale: Housing values often conflict in relationships—location vs. space vs. cost vs. flexibility. This is one of the biggest financial decisions couples make, and values here matter enormously.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different housing values require real negotiation. The location-prioritizer may clash with the space-prioritizer; the affordability-focuser may clash with both. What's non-negotiable for each of you?
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared housing values make one of life's biggest decisions easier. You'll naturally agree on what matters in a home.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What's most important to you in where you live? What would you sacrifice for it?

therapeutic.rationale: Spending preferences reveal what brings you joy and meaning. Travel-lovers value novelty; home-lovers value sanctuary; food-lovers value pleasure; hobby-spenders value passion. Knowing your partner's joy-spending helps you support it.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different joy-spending can feel like the other doesn't value what you value. The traveler may not understand the home-investor; the foodie may not understand the hobbyist. Respect each other's joy source.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared joy-spending makes life planning fun. You'll naturally want to invest in the same things.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What do you love spending money on? What feels like a waste to you?

questions.text: If our incomes changed significantly, I'd want us to...
choices: Maintain our current lifestyle as much as possible
Use the change to pursue what matters most
Have a conversation about what it means for us

therapeutic.rationale: How you respond to income changes reveals adaptability and values. Adjusters are flexible; maintainers value stability; opportunity-seekers reprioritize; talkers process together. Changes—up or down—test these instincts.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different change responses can create tension during transitions. The adjuster may feel the maintainer is in denial; the maintainer may feel the adjuster is overreacting. Talk about the change before making decisions.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared change response means you'll navigate transitions similarly. This alignment helps during uncertain times.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How have you handled financial changes in the past? What helped? What would you do differently?
